title: Kamala Harris Gets a Fracking Education
summary: Pence is right: Shale drilling for natural gas has cut C02 emissions.

title: Stocks Climb to Close Best Week in Three Months
summary: U.S. stocks edged higher, giving the S&P 500 its biggest weekly advance in three months as investors welcomed signs pointing to a decisive result in next month’s presidential election.

title: USDA Report: World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates
PE Daily: A Harvard Spin Out | Heritage Closes Fund III | Seaside’s Debut Fund Gains Traction
summary: Few would dispute that raising a first, or even second, fund can be challenging, even in the best of times. Uncertain economic times such as these ones we are currently experiencing makes a hard task even harder. Against that backdrop, it’s all the more noteworthy that our top stories today involve new firms or, in one case, a firm that’s just forming. As Dawn Lim and Juliet Chung report for The Wall Street Journal, Harvard Management Co. is supporting the spinout of its natural resources team, while I have news of some progress that Seaside Equity Partners has made on its debut fund. Finally, although not a debut fund, New Heritage Capital’s latest offering has wrapped up with some $270 million, as our own Preeti Singh reports.

title: Fed’s Rosengren Says Pre-Pandemic Risk-Taking Likely Slowing Recovery; George Says Recovery Outpacing Expectations; RBI Holds Steady
summary: Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said yesterday the low-interest-rate environment before the pandemic is making the U.S. economic recovery more difficult. Kansas City Fed leader Esther George, meanwhile, said the economy has snapped back faster than expected, but it’s unclear what will happen next. Elsewhere, India’s central bank kept policy unchanged, Bank of Canada Gov. Tiff Macklem warned that ultralow rates increase the risk that more households will become overleveraged, and the Reserve Bank of Australia warned of a potential rise in loan defaults. And meeting minutes showed Bank of Mexico board members split on whether the bank should pause its yearlong easing cycle.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Exxon Turbo Boost, Tech Buyout Fantasies, Stashing Cash
summary: Higher crude prices could magnify Exxon's chemicals segment’s earnings; tech giants probably won’t be able to buy their way to growth anytime soon, and figuring out where is the best place to store cash.

title: The Oil Market Has an Aviation Problem
summary: Passenger-flight activity is mired at around half of pre-pandemic levels, leaving a hole in global oil demand that is hampering crude prices.

title: Stocks Climb to Highest Level Since Early September
summary: Investors remain hopeful that Congress will reach an agreement on narrow fiscal-stimulus measures aimed at parts of the economy, despite new hurdles.

title: Peak Oil? OPEC Says the World’s Richest Countries Are Already There
summary: The world’s thirst for oil is unlikely to peak for two more decades but may already have crested in the U.S. and other wealthier countries, according to a forecast by OPEC.

title: Russia’s Siberian Waters See Record Ship Traffic as Ice Melt Accelerates
summary: The Arctic has gone through its warmest summer on record, and with the ice melting, more ships than ever are sailing along Russia’s Siberian coast, underscoring its role as a growing energy transport corridor and potential as a new ocean trade route.

title: Saudis Consider Canceling OPEC Plans to Boost Output
summary: The debate inside Saudi Arabia comes amid weaker-than-expected oil demand, as Covid-19 cases in many parts of the world rise and the expected return of Libyan crude threatens to swell global supplies.

title: Hackers Eye Their Next Targets, From Schools to Cars
summary: Systems that are secure today may not be tomorrow. Here’s what cybersecurity experts say could be a future focus for attacks.

title: There’s No Oil in Wisconsin. The Fracking Bust Hit It Anyway.
summary: Mines that sent trainloads of “Northern White” sand to West Texas for hydraulic fracturing sit idle, costing jobs and hurting local-government coffers.

title: Harvard Spins Out Natural-Resources Team, Ending Long Chapter at Endowment
summary: The university’s endowment has spun out its natural-resources team into an independent investment firm that will take over some of the endowment’s portfolio of orchards, farms and plantations.

title: Saudi Staycations Lay Bare Obstacles to Kingdom’s Tourism Drive
summary: With international travel constrained, many Saudi residents are exploring the kingdom, some for the first time, but most attractions lack basic infrastructure.

title: Banks’ Arctic Financing Retreat Rattles Oil Industry
summary: Defenders of the oil-and-gas industry are fighting back against banks who want to stop financing new Arctic-drilling projects, fearing it could be a harbinger of an unbankable future for fossil-fuel companies.

title: Hydrogen’s Dirty Little Secret
summary: Most of this emission-free gas is currently produced using fossil fuels and a lot of work is required to clean it up.

title: Exxon Could Get a Chemical Turbo Boost if Oil Rebounds
summary: Higher crude prices are good for petrochemical producers weighted toward North America and the Middle East—such as Exxon—because those gains make their products based on natural-gas liquids more competitive.

title: Electric Trash Trucks Are Coming Quietly to Your Town
summary: Hoping to lower emissions and silence early pickups that rattle us awake, trash truck manufacturers are rolling out EV prototypes. Dan Neil tests Mack’s LR Electric.

title: Sugar Touches Seven-Month High
summary: Sugar prices hit their highest level since early March on Tuesday, lifted by supply disruptions. But a new wave of lockdowns and elevated production from heavyweight Brazil threaten to dull the sugar high.

title: Soybeans Rise in Reaction to Higher Palm Oil Futures
Utex Industries to Shed $700 Million Debt Through Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Utex Industries said it plans to file for chapter 11 bankruptcy after striking a deal with the majority of lenders that will reduce its funded debt by about $700 million.

title: Companies Give Up Cash Cushions to Buy Back Debt
summary: Companies in the U.S. and Europe are buying back bonds to reduce the cash piles they built up earlier this year, signaling expectations for more stable economic times ahead.

title: Dotcom Trailblazer Is Now Betting on Green Energy
summary: Bill Gross, who runs tech incubator Idealab, is trying to replicate with renewable energy the success and fortune he achieved in fostering numerous internet-related startups.

title: Blackstone to Lose Control of Shale Driller in $50 Million Bankruptcy Sale
summary: The private-equity firm’s Gavilan Resources has agreed to sell itself out of bankruptcy to its drilling partner Mesquite Energy for $50 million, a stark indication of the value erosion in the U.S. shale sector.

title: 10 Things You Didn't Know About Somali Pirates
summary: Wiping out today's pirates won't be easy; they're smarter, better organized, and, frankly, better loved abroad than the swashbucklers of yesteryear. In a special dispatch from Mombasa, Kenya, Mental Floss correspondent David Axe explains.

title: The Covid Economy Carves Deep Divide Between Haves and Have-Nots
summary: The comeback since the start of the pandemic is kind to those who can work from home, to firms serving them and to regions hospitable to them. Left behind are the less-educated, old-line businesses and areas dependent on tourism. Rising wealth coincides with lines at food banks.

title: U.S. Boosts Crude Sales to China, Forcing Saudis to Find Other Markets
summary: The U.S. is quickly ramping up oil sales to China, the world’s biggest importer, forcing traditional suppliers in the Mideast to look for new markets or hold on to their crude in an already oversupplied world.

title: WSJ Wealth Adviser Briefing: Reason for Investors to Look Away, Private Debt, Athletes Conquer Distance
summary: It would be difficult to imagine a U.S. election subject to more uncertainty than this year’s; Canadian pensions find opportunity in private debt, and athletes are conquering distance -- sports will never be the same.

title: 401(k)s Could Become Even Less Welcoming to ‘Do Good’ ESG Funds
summary: A proposed Labor Department regulation would make it harder for these funds to be offered in retirement accounts.

title: From Baking to Sous Vide, This Smart Steam Oven Is Your New Kitchen BFF
summary: The Anova Precision Oven combines the power of steam cooking with an app full of recipes that instruct you every step of the way.

title: How to Buy the Softest T-shirt Online
summary: It’s time to replace those tattered WFH tees that you’ve relied on, but how can you assess the feel of cotton when shopping through a screen? Consult this expert guide—the next-best-thing to a touch test.

title: How to Avoid Paying the Cruelest Tax: Inflation
summary: Investors worried that record budget deficits and massive Fed bond buying will stoke a big rise in inflation have places to hide aside from hoarding gold coins—some of them surprising.

title: Bankrupt Fracker Sable Permian to Sell to Bank Lenders
summary: Sable Permian Resources has agreed to sell itself to bank lenders, all but wiping out more than $700 million of debt held by secured bondholders.

title: Transcript: WSJ in Conversation With Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan
summary: Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan discussed the September jobs report, the Federal Reserve’s response to the coronavirus crisis and the importance of fiscal support from the government during the pandemic.

title: PE Daily: Florida’s IPO Windfall | Quantum’s Bold Fundraising | Canada’s Pensions Feast on Private Debt
summary: The third quarter is officially behind us. As we head into the final stretch of 2020, the U.S. economy still faces some formidable obstacles on the road to recovery, including lower household income and mountains of debt.

title: Tesla, Amazon.com, Uber, Twilio: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stock futures fell sharply after President Trump and the first lady tested positive for the coronavirus.

summary: The Houston firm is aiming to raise $5 billion for its latest flagship fund at one of the most difficult fundraising moments for energy managers in recent memory.

title: Lime Rock Partners Reunites with Arena Energy
summary: Arena Energy LP said Thursday it has emerged from bankruptcy with backing from Lime Rock Partners, reuniting the offshore oil and gas driller with the energy-focused private-equity firm 14 years after they backed their first deal together.

title: Pandemic Pain Persists for Big Oil Companies
summary: Major oil companies signaled they remain under extreme financial pressure and oil prices slid Thursday as demand for fossil fuels rebounds slowly after being crushed by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Oil’s Recovery Set to Drag On Beyond Next Year
summary: Crude prices late next year will remain well short of the level they hit in the weeks before coronavirus-induced travel restrictions and lockdowns began to weigh on prices, investment banks say.

title: Wheat Futures Give Back Gains; Export Sales Exceed Expectations
Shale Driller Lonestar Resources Files Prepackaged Chapter 11
summary: Lonestar Resources US Inc. has become the latest shale driller tipped into bankruptcy during the coronavirus pandemic and will seek to implement a prenegotiated restructuring plan to trim about $390 million in debt and hand control to its bondholders.

title: Venezuela’s Food Chain Is Breaking, and Millions Go Hungry
summary: Venezuela is facing one of the world’s worst food crises as a gasoline shortage makes it harder for farmers to produce and deliver their goods. A recent U.N.-sponsored report found that about one-third of Venezuelans lacks sufficient food.

title: Brett Icahn to Rejoin His Father’s Firm
summary: Carl Icahn will remain in charge of Icahn Enterprises for now, but the company will adopt a plan for his son Brett to succeed him as chairman and chief executive of its investment segment within seven years.

title: Federal Reserve Caps Big Banks’ Dividends for Fourth Quarter; Boston Fed’s Rosengren Worries About Risks to Lending
summary: The Federal Reserve said big U.S. banks will face restrictions on dividends and share buybacks for another three months to ensure they maintain a “high level of capital resilience.” The Fed noted that “The capital positions of large banks have remained strong during the third quarter while such restrictions were in place.” Meantime, Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren in an interview with The Wall Street Journal said he is concerned about the potential for losses on business debt and commercial real estate leading to tighter lending standards from small and mid-size banks.

title: These Stocks Have Rallied More Than 400% This Year
summary: The stock market’s star performers are shining brighter than ever and creating a stark divide with the rest of the pack.

title: Oasis Petroleum Is Latest Driller to Join Bankruptcy Parade
summary: Oasis Petroleum said it has filed for bankruptcy with a deal to pare its debt load by $1.8 billion, becoming the latest energy company driven into chapter 11 by a volatile oil-and-gas market.

title: Copper Rises After Upbeat Chinese Economic Data
summary: The industrial metal has risen about 8% for the year and recovered roughly 40% in the past six months following an early-year selloff.

title: Oil Giant Total Pledges Renewable Power Push
summary: Total SA pledged to ramp up its spending on renewable energy and reduce its dependence on petroleum, the latest move by a major oil company toward cleaner power.

title: Superior Energy Services Plans Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Superior Energy Services said it plans to file for chapter 11 bankruptcy after striking a deal with the majority of its noteholders that would convert all $1.3 billion of its funded debt into equity.

summary: Some extreme investor positioning suggests the summer’s weak dollar could rebound, to the detriment of stocks and commodities.

title: Kuwait to Face Pressure to Forge Ties With Israel After Emir’s Death
summary: leaves his successor with a dilemma: whether or not to normalize ties with Israel without statehood for the Palestinians.

title: BP Bets Future on Green Energy, but Investors Remain Wary
summary: BP has unveiled the most aggressive plans yet by a major oil company to pivot toward cleaner energy. But the revamp has so far failed to ignite enthusiasm among investors despite growing interest in renewables.

title: Cooling Demand Recovery Keeps Oil Stuck Around $40
summary: The trend is challenging the global energy industry heading into the final months of the year.

title: Shale Merger Promises Big Payout, Just Not Yet
summary: Being a small fish in the world of gigantic energy majors is tough, especially when oil prices remain low. Consolidation seems to be a sensible answer for Devon Energy and WPX Energy.

title: Devon Energy, WPX to Merge in All-Stock Deal
summary: The combination of shale drillers would have a combined market value of about $6 billion and fortify them against the sharp drop in oil demand caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Joe Biden Wants to Make Almost Every Policy a Climate Change Policy
summary: Joe Biden’s plans to make climate change a major focus of his administration if he wins the White House would have significant ramifications for both businesses and consumers.

title: Devon Energy, WPX in Talks to Merge
summary: The companies are in talks to combine, according to people familiar with the matter, in a move that could help the energy companies weather a prolonged industry slump.

title: Captive Insurance Seen as Covid-Era Remedy to Rising Premiums
summary: With fights flaring over payouts during a time of disrupted business, many companies are looking beyond mainstream coverage and doing it themselves.

title: Europe Invites a Trade Battle in its Fight Against Shipping Pollution
summary: A plan to make oceangoing ships pay for the pollution they cause carrying cargo to and from Europe is drawing sharp criticism from the industry and raises the prospect of a broader conflict on trade.

title: Emerging and Growth Markets, September 26th 2020
summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: Valaris Bondholders Win Dispute Over Bankruptcy Financing
summary: Investors backing the offshore oil rig operator’s $7.1 billion balance-sheet restructuring have prevailed against a group of banks in a dispute over which party would fund the company’s chapter 11 case, a development likely to dictate who will control Valaris when it leaves bankruptcy.

title: Beyond Meat’s Pitch for More Customers: It’s Not Just Good for the Planet, It’s Also Good for You.
summary: Companies that aim to win converts to green products need to convince consumers that they’re also acting in their own best interests.

title: Noble Settles Multibillion-Dollar Suit Over Paragon Spinoff
summary: The London-based operator of offshore oil-and-gas drilling rigs has settled multibillion-dollar litigation over its 2014 spinoff of Paragon Offshore, a critical step in Noble’s path to exiting bankruptcy.

title: Fed Officials Press Washington for Fiscal Policy Boost; A Bumpy Start for New Guidance Strategy
summary: Federal Reserve officials stepped up their calls for additional government spending to support the U.S. economic recovery, with Chairman Jerome Powell and his colleagues saying Congress and the White House, more than the Fed, have the power to hasten a faster rebound from the deep slump caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The Chicago Fed’s Charles Evans also pushed back against the idea that he wants to raise rates before overshooting the Fed’s 2% inflation goal—an example of how the central bank’s new interest rate guidance, as Michael S. Derby writes, is having a bumpy rollout.

title: Norges Bank Still Sees Key Rate at Zero for Next Couple of Years
summary: Norway’s central bank held rates steady, as expected, and said a recent increase in coronavirus infection rates could put the brakes on the summer’s economic upswing.

title: Wheat Futures Fall On Supply Growth Signals
Powell, Mnuchin Urge Congress to Loosen Purse Strings; Evans Comments Show Hunger for Fed Strategy Details
summary: Jerome Powell and Steven Mnuchin told Congress the U.S. economic recovery needs more fiscal stimulus. Mr. Powell pointed out to lawmakers the rebound had been sustained in part with the $2.2 trillion relief measure Congress approved in March, which included more generous unemployment benefits and grants to small businesses. Separately, Mr. Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi struck a deal on a bill for short-term funding for the federal government. The House approved the legislation, which requires Senate approval. And Chicago Fed President Charles Evans grabbed traders’ attention when he offered a fairly straightforward explanation of how the Fed’s new framework works and what its interest-rate guidance means.

title: PE Daily: Hamilton Lane Taps Yett as ESG Chief | Warburg Backs Salsify | Investment Consulting World Shrinks
summary: The virtual convening of the United Nations general assembly sent yet another danger signal to New York City Hall this week, even as East Side residents could look forward to less motorcade-driven traffic jams. The absence of the UN’s diplomatic hordes provides another hint of a bleak municipal future. While the federal government threatens to cut billions of dollars in city aid and business leaders press Mayor Bill de Blasio to do more to restore New York, the customary throngs of white collar workers and tourists in Manhattan’s office tower canyons are still largely absent, and so are their sales taxes. Pedestrian traffic in Times Square recovered slightly in July from June but remained down over 78% from last year, according to a business district group. As private-equity industry data show, more firms are adjusting to the new virtual ways of doing business. That may not bode well for high-priced places like New York.

title: Saudi Arabia to Resume Religious Tourism in Bid to Revive Economy
summary: The kingdom plans to reopen the two holiest sites in Islam to pilgrims in October, seven months after it suspended visits to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, as it attempts to revive its floundering economy.

title: Peak Oil Is Already Shifting Markets
summary: The prospect of falling demand for crude oil could unleash a long-term scramble between rival producer nations.

title: CME, Nasdaq to Launch Water Futures Contract
summary: Farmers are known to pray for rain. Now they can hedge against unanswered invocations. CME Group and Nasdaq are planning to launch a futures contract later this year that will allow farmers, speculators and others to wager on the price of water.

title: House Passes Short-Term Spending Bill to Keep Government Funded Through Dec. 11
summary: The House passed a short-term spending bill keeping the government funded through Dec. 11, after Democrats reached a deal with the White House over farm aid and food assistance. The Senate is expected to vote on it this week.

title: Fracking-Services Company FTS International Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Texas-based FTS International filed for bankruptcy protection after reaching an agreement with creditors on a debt-for-equity swap following a downturn in the energy sector and lower demand for its services.

title: Oil Market Flies Blind as Virus Clouds Demand Outlook
summary: Predicting oil demand has rarely been more challenging. Energy analysts are mapping out the course of the coronavirus and efforts to stop the pandemic, as well as grappling with the effects on fuel demand of an economic downturn.

title: Hot Oil Field Was Desperate for Pipelines. Now It Has Too Many.
summary: The Southwest’s Permian Basin has become a headache for pipeline operators with the pandemic damping oil demand after they had added capacity.

title: Powell Calls for Government Action to Aid Recovery; Kaplan Says New Guidance May Tie Fed’s Hands; First Step Toward CRA Rewrite
summary: Jerome Powell said in remarks prepared for a congressional hearing today that the Fed stands ready to do what it can for as long as it takes to help the U.S. economic recovery. He added that the path forward depends on controlling the coronavirus and “policy actions taken at all levels of government.” Meanwhile, Dallas Fed leader Robert Kaplan, one of two officials to vote against the Fed’s policy statement last week, said its new guidance may restrict policy makers’ scope to act in future. And Fed governors voted to seek public comment on a broad overhaul to rules for the Community Reinvestment Act.

summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Getting the Complex Geopolitics of Energy Right
summary: A price or limit on climate pollution would create an economic incentive for industry to slash emissions, which would shift costs from citizens to emitters.

title: Stocks Decline Sharply; Dow Drops More Than 500 Points
summary: The Dow industrials dropped 1.8%, falling in tandem with oil and gold prices. Investors see dwindling prospects for a new stimulus package amid the campaign season.

title: Commodity Prices Retreat, Hurt by Dollar’s Advance
summary: Oil prices dropped on fears that some of Libya’s long-blockaded crude would return to the market, adding to the global glut. The losses spilled from industrial commodities into precious metals.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Garrett Motion Eyes $2.1 Billion Bankruptcy Sale; Retail Gift-Card Holders Fight Back; Teamsters Union Fights Private Equity Over Pensions
summary: Automotive supplier Garrett Motion Inc. filed for bankruptcy, proposing a $2.1 billion sale to private-equity firm KPS Capital Partners. The filing, which sets up a conflict with former parent company Honeywell International over asbestos liabilities, confirmed Friday’s exclusive reporting in WSJ Pro Bankruptcy.

title: The S&P 500’s Hottest Sector: Materials
summary: Shares of the companies that mine or make raw materials are lately trading like once-hot technology stocks. The S&P 500’s materials sector is up around 5.4% this month, even as the broader index has fallen more than 4%.

title: Trump’s Targeted Moves Seek to Shore Up Support for GOP Senators
summary: With elections closing in, the White House is stepping up its efforts through policy changes and direct spending to support Republican candidates in competitive races. Democrats call the moves superficial fixes.

summary: A weekly roundup of key news affecting emerging and growth markets from the Wall Street Journal and beyond.

title: ‘Sustainable’ Investing Is a Self-Defeating Strategy
summary: If, say, oil stocks sell at low prices relative to earnings and prospects, those who buy them stand to gain.

Wheat Futures Stretch Gains as Russian Prices Rise
Cocoa Price Hits 1 Million Naira in Nigeria Due to Currency Depreciation -- Traders
Saudi Royal Family Divides Over Potential Embrace of Israel
summary: King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman have been at odds over whether to ease relations with the Jewish state. Israel’s deal with the U.A.E. stunned the 84-year-old monarch. Normalizing relations between Saudi Arabia and Israel before any deal for Palestinian statehood would be a seismic shift in the Middle East.

title: Today’s Logistics Report: Planning Vaccine Delivery; Germany’s Export Cloud; Assembling Ford Trucks
summary: Today’s Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ.

summary: Bond investors regained their appetite for emerging markets; major airline executives made a final plea for government aid to avoid job losses, and defeated quarantine gardeners have thrown in the trowel.

title: In Boston, a Developer Is Turning His Childhood Home Into $1 Million Condos
summary: Frank Williams watched the city’s South End neighborhood change before his eyes. Now, he’s one of the few lifelong residents reaping the benefits of the area’s real-estate boom.

title: Can’t Travel to Paris? Bistro Chairs Bring Cafe Culture to Your Kitchen
summary: An erstwhile visitor rues not buying a set of the city’s distinctive bistro chairs last time she was there, so she takes to the internet.

title: Bond Investors Regain Appetite for Emerging Markets
summary: The collapse of bond yields in the developed world is driving investors back into battered emerging markets, fueling gains despite a series of high-profile defaults and concerns about the pandemic’s blow to fragile economies.

title: Oil Rallies on Surprise Supply Drop
summary: Oil prices climbed, after unexpectedly upbeat U.S. inventory numbers extended a rally that began Tuesday.

title: PE Daily: Warburg Backs Tech Outfit With $1 Billion | An Oil Patch Growth Story | Calpers Resets on Private Equity
summary: Today we offer an exclusive from our Laura Cooper on a new technology investment group backed by nearly $1 billion from Warburg Pincus. And Luis Garcia has an unusual story from the oil patch about a company that’s growing despite the sector’s woes, while Preeti Singh has a look at how Calpers is trying to get its private-equity strategy back on track.

title: Facebook, FedEx and Nikola: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens
summary: Facebook shares are ticking down. The FTC is gearing up to file a possible antitrust lawsuit against the social-media company.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Ligado in Talks to Restructure About $8 Billion in Debt | Flywheel Sports to Close | Vivus Fails to Win OK of Icahn-Backed Chapter 11 Plan
summary: Ligado Networks LLC, the wireless venture formerly known as LightSquared, is in talks to restructure close to $8 billion of debt and equity as it waits to get its 5G project off the ground, write WSJ’s Alex Gladstone and Andrew Scurria. Flywheel Sports Inc., spin boutique operator that recently settled a bruising patent fight with Peloton Interactive, is shutting down. And Vivus Inc., a drugmaker focused on obesity treatment, will go back to the drawing board after a bankruptcy judge rejected the company’s plan to sell its business to Carl Icahn’s investment firm.

title: U.S. Gas Exporters Eye Europe’s Surging Prices
summary: Natural-gas prices have surged in Europe, offering good news for exporters that invested in infrastructure for shipping it over the past decade, only to contend with a collapse in sales when the pandemic struck.

title: Top Tier Capital Partners Doubles Down on GoExpedi
summary: Expedi, a provider of e-commerce services to the energy industry under the GoExpedi brand, raised $25 million through an investment that values the growth-stage company at about $225 million.

title: Business Shifts From Resistance to Action on Climate
summary: In a sign of how much corporate attitudes have changed, the Business Roundtable, one of the country’s most prominent business groups, is throwing its support behind broad-based measures to slash greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Pipeline Politics Tests Merkel’s Mettle
summary: Alexei Navalny succeeds where Trump fell short, in undermining the case for Nord Stream 2.

title: Wheat Drops on Larger World Supplies
Oil Rises as Hurricane Season Disrupts U.S. Supply
summary: Oil prices rose, clawing back some of their losses from recent weeks, with hurricane season limiting supply from the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Industrial Production Points to Slowing Manufacturing Recovery
summary: U.S. industrial production rose for the fourth consecutive month in August but at a much lower rate than earlier in the summer.

title: Apple, Tesla, NextEra Gain: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens
summary: Apple shares are ticking up ahead of its much-hyped annual product reveal event, though investors won't get a peek at the newest smartphone.

title: Fed Meeting Starts; Powell Adviser Named Monetary Affairs Chief; Man Behind ‘Evans Rule’ Sees New Rate Guidance Challenges
summary: Fed officials are about to start their two-day meeting, where they are expected to wrestle with how to put meat on the bones of their new average inflation framework. The central bank yesterday named Trevor Reeve as director of its monetary affairs division. Mr. Reeve was involved in key decisions while serving as the division’s deputy director since 2017. And Chicago Fed leader Charles Evans, who helped shape the Fed’s financial crisis-era interest-rate guidance, reckons that any new effort on this front will be trickier to pull off.

title: Lonestar Resources Reaches Deal to Restructure Under Chapter 11
summary: Lonestar Resources US said it plans to file for chapter 11 bankruptcy after reaching a restructuring support agreement that will eliminate roughly $390 million in debt obligations and preferred equity interests..

title: German Stocks Show Strength in Europe’s Battered Market
summary: German stocks have outpaced European rivals since the coronavirus-driven market selloff bottomed out in March, reflecting the advantages of strong balance sheets and exports to China.

title: The Long Road to Israel’s Very Good Month
summary: The Jewish state has become too valuable to the Arab world to be treated as a pariah.

title: Trump Administration Denies Retroactive Biofuel Exemptions in Boost for Iowa
summary: Republicans warned that approving oil refiners’ biofuel waiver requests could hurt the re-election campaigns of President Trump and Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst.

title: OPEC Extends Forecast for Decline in Global Oil Demand
summary: The economic hit from the coronavirus pandemic will hurt global energy demand harder and for longer than previously feared, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said.

title: After Navalny Poisoning, Putin’s Loyalists Win Big in Russian Elections
summary: Forces allied with Russian dissident Alexei Navalny scored a few symbolic victories, but candidates loyal to President Vladimir Putin broadly dominated.

title: An Investor Bought a Coral Gables Home for $27.8 Million Last Year. Now He’s Relisting It for $49.9 Million.
summary: Steven Lempera purchased the 14,000-square-foot estate in an online auction for far less than its original $68 million asking price.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Discount Retailer Century 21 Is Shutting Down | Judge Rejects Latam Airlines DIP Loan | Creditors Blast Tuesday Morning Executives Over Sale Process
summary: Century 21, which for years offered New Yorkers big discounts on designer goods in the shadow of the Twin Towers, is shutting down after failing to wring Covid-19 concessions from its insurers. A bankruptcy judge rejected a $2.45 billion bankruptcy loan for Latam Airlines Group SA, which creditors had criticized as a sweetheart deal for some big shareholders. And Tuesday Morning executives are making a “desperate” attempt to try to save their jobs at the bankrupt home-goods discount chain by ignoring potential buyers, a group of creditors says.

title: Stocks Close Lower After Early Gains
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 lost momentum through the day as weekly jobless claims held steady, pausing Wednesday’s rebound after a recent technology-led selloff.

title: Jane Fraser to Succeed Michael Corbat as Citi CEO
summary: Jane Fraser will become the first woman to run a major Wall Street bank, succeeding Michael Corbat as Citigroup chief executive when he retires in February.

title: Nasdaq and Tesla Up: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Stock market futures are trending up into Thursday's market open, with jobless claims coming in slightly higher than expected.

title: PE Daily: Mass PRIM Predicts PE Rebound | Energy Alloys Files for Bankruptcy | A Railroad Rejection
summary: Public stocks aren’t the only assets that seem to be on the rebound. As our own Preeti Singh reports, Massachusetts’ state pension manager is seeing signs of a rebound in its private-equity portfolio, with valuations and deal flow picking up in some sectors.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Mall Owners Rescue J.C. Penney | Canada-based Women’s Clothing Retailer Seeks Protection From Creditors | Blackstone’s Energy Alloys Files for Chapter 11
summary: J.C. Penney will survive after mall owners Simon Property Group Inc. and Brookfield Property Partners LP agreed to pay $300 million in cash and forgive $500 million in debt as part of a deal that values the post-bankruptcy department store chain at $1.75 billion. Montreal-based Groupe Dynamite Inc., which owns more than 300 Garage and Dynamite women’s clothing stores in the U.S. and Canada, sought protection from creditors in both countries after landlords balked at its “Covid-19-adjusted rental model.” And Blackstone’s Energy Alloys, a specialty metals supplier to the oil-and-gas industry, filed for bankruptcy.

title: Fed Officials Debate Implementation of New Framework; Bank of Canada Keeps Key Rate Unchanged
summary: Ahead of their September meeting, Fed officials are debating how exactly to implement their new framework governing how they will conduct policy over the long run. Elsewhere, the Bank of Canada kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged, saying it expects a faster third-quarter recovery than it had previously anticipated. On the agenda today we have a policy statement from the European Central Bank.

title: Oil Traders Gird for More Price Swings
summary: Traders are betting on fresh upheaval in the oil market, in an abrupt turnaround from the calm of recent months.
